title: Wayne Bennett urges Great Britain to learn key lessons from Hamilton defeat to Tonga
text:

Great Britain coach Wayne Bennett highlighted a lack of patience and execution as key reasons for the Lions’ opening tour defeat to a Tonga Invitational XIII in Hamilton.

Bennett’s side fell to a 6-14 loss with John Bateman’s try not enough to inspire a late comeback - and the Lions also lost Luke Thompson and Oliver Gildart to injury, potentially for the whole tour.

The veteran Australian coach said his side quickly needs to learn what is needed to succeed on the international stage if they are to bounce back against New Zealand and Papua New Guinea.

Bennett said: “We didn’t fall down in effort - we fell down a bit in execution, being patience and the kicking game. They are the areas that really hurt us in the end, but not a lack of effort.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Defensively we were very good I thought. We just need to pick up a bit with our patience and discipline with the football.

“They’re a quality football team with a lot of quality players in that team, and I don’t think and of us, in the Australian comp certainly, doubted that we would have a tough game. It proved to be that, and they had a bit of luck as well.

“I noticed in the 9s last week there were a couple of things that put us under pressure and I didn’t like that. I thought we’d got that out of our game last year and the year before - we need to get that right again.

“What you saw in the first half tonight is what you’ve got to be able to play week-in and week-out. They had one handling error and one penalty against them in the first half. If we can’t do that we can’t be the team I know we want to be.

(Image: Getty Images)

“We weren’t far off that first half by the way, we were pretty close to that mark. But that’s the standard.”

Asked who impressed him in the Lions side, Bennett responded: “John Bateman really came into his own in the second half there a fair bit, but outside of that I wasn’t that excited abut anyone else. It wasn’t a lack of effort and they were up against it at times when we weren’t kicking great.

“Second half we turned the ball over in vital field positions at different stages when we had them under pressure, and we gave away three seven-tackle sets. Stuff like that takes away your energy to do anything with the football because you spend too much time defending.”

On the injuries to Thompson and Gildart, Bennett added: “I don’t think they’ll probably play again this series. Thompson has a rib issue and Gildart a dislocated shoulder.

“I’m happy with the squad, we can cover. We’ve got the best players in England here so at the moment it’s not panic time for us.”
description: Luke Thompson and Oliver Gildart could miss the remainder of the tour with injury
